Detailed Description

Table schema.

Author:
Weihai Yu

A table schema defines a number of data fields. A table record holds the data values whose types are defined in the schema.

Use new_schema() to create an empty new schema, new_int_field() and new_str_field() to create a new field, and add_field() to add a field to a schema.

Use get_schema() to get a schema, and schema_first_fld_desc(), schema_last_fld_desc() and field_desc_next() to nevigate through the fields of the schema.

Since the data types of record fields are not known at compile time, generic pointer (void *) is used in many places and must be cast to the right C types. The types of a record's fields are maintained in field descriptors of the corresponding schema. Therefore operations on records and record fields are typically associated with a schema, and navigating the fields of a record involves navigating in parallel the field descriptors of the schema. See the source code of put_record_info and fill_record ect. as examples of how to access field values of a record.

The memory of a record is allocated with new_record() and released with release_record(). Assign field valuse to a record with assign_int_field(), assign_str_field() or fill_record(). Compare if two records have equal values with equal_record(). Access the record at the current position of a page with get_record() and put_record().

Typedef Documentation

typedef struct field_desc_struct* field_desc_p

Definition at line 52 of file schema.h.

typedef void** record

Data record.

A record consists of an array of pointers to field values. Because in general, the types of the fields of a record are unknown at compile time, the memory of these values has to be allocated at run time with new_record. When accessing these values, the generic (void *) pointers must be casted to the correct C types (int *) and (char *). See the source code of put_record_info and fill_record as examples of how to access field values of a record.
